right.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a statement or piece of information that is right is correct and based on true facts
right.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I got most of the questions right.
His ideas have now been proved right.
right.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if you are right, you have said something that is correct and based on true facts
right.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: I think you’re right. We should have set out earlier.
I think the prime minister is only half right.
Am I right in thinking that you two have met before?
You were right about the hotel being too crowded.
right.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: the right thing, person, method etc is the one that is most suitable or effective
right.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: I think you’ve made the right decision.
I think she’s definitely the right person for the job.
A huge development like this isn’t right for such a small village.
right.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: your right side is the side with the hand that most people write with
right.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: He had a knife in his right hand.
a scar on the right side of her face
right.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: on the same side of something as your right side
right.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: the right bank of the river
right.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: something that is not right is not in the state it should be in
right.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: Things haven’t been right between me and James for some time.
It didn’t take long to find the fault and put it right.
right.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: if someone is right to do something, their action is morally correct or sensible
right.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: It’s only right (=completely right) that he should get his share of the money.
The company wants to do the right thing and offer compensation to all the injured workers.
Do you think I was right to report them to the police?
It can’t be right to keep lying to your family.
I think it’s right that the people who work hardest should earn the most.
right.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: used to emphasize how bad someone or something is
right.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: He sounds like a right idiot!
The house was in a right mess when we got back.
right.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: if you are not feeling right, you are not feeling completely well
right.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: I haven’t been feeling right all day.
A few days in bed will soon put you right.
You’ll soon be as right as rain (=completely healthy).
right.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: the right people, places, schools etc are considered to be the best or most important
right.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: Sonia’s always careful to be seen with the right people.
right.translation[0].note_box[0].section: You were quite right – we should never have gone with them.
My figures may not be exactly right.
You were dead right not to trust him.
That theory may still be partly right.
For once, he got my name right.
We warned that it would not work, and we have been proved right.
I think I’m right in saying they once employed 2000 people.
right.translation[0].note_box[1].section: not wrong – used about something someone says, or about the person who says it
the right answer
You were right about the colour.
‘He’s about thirty, isn’t he?’ ‘That’s right.’
correct
right. Correct sounds more formal than right
the correct answer
He is absolutely correct.
Unfortunately, this information is not correct.
right – used about information, measurements, descriptions etc
Make sure that your measurements are accurate.
an accurate description of the suspect
exact
an exact number, amount, or time is completely correct, and is no more and no less than it should be
The exact time is 9.28 a.m.
The exact weight of the baby was 3.3 kilos.
spot-on
exactly right – used especially about guesses or things people say
His answer was spot-on.
You’re spot-on.
right.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: exactly in a particular position or place
right.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: I left my bags right here.
She was standing right in the middle of the room.
right in/in front of/by etc something
There’s the house, right in front of you.
right in/in front of/by etc something
right.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: It’s on right after the six o'clock news.
I could tell right off that something was wrong.
Kay answered right off the bat.
right.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: ‘I thought you’d be cross.’ ‘You thought right!’
right.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: in a way that is good or satisfactory
right.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: Everything’s going right for him at the moment.
It’ll work out right in the end.
right.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: towards the direction or side that is on the right
right.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: something that you are morally, legally, or officially allowed to do or have
right.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The new charter establishes the rights and duties of citizens.
Everyone should have the right to freedom of expression.
You have the right to consult a lawyer.
The money is yours by right.
You would be within your rights to sue the company for negligence.
right.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: behaviour that is morally good and correct
right.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Some kids don’t seem to know the difference between right and wrong.
The protesters believe that they have right on their side.
right.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: a hit made with your right hand
right.translation[2].note_box[0].section: People have a right to know the truth.
Imprisoning the men without trial violated their rights.
The insurance company decided not to exercise its right of appeal.
Women were denied the right to vote.
We demand the same rights that other European workers enjoy.
We should defend our right to demonstrate.
I will uphold the rights of the people of this country.
This company always operates with respect for human rights.
As a young man, he was deeply involved in the struggle for civil rights.
The law recognises a man’s fundamental right to defend his home and his property.
Banks have the legal right to recover their money.
Teachers have a constitutional right to join a union.
New laws have been passed to protect women’s rights.
The company’s actions are a violation of workers’ rights.
Animal rights campaigners say the dogs are being bred in terrible conditions.
In these circumstances, there is no right of appeal.
The judge decided that the media’s actions violated the couple’s right to privacy.
You have rights of access to data held about you.
People should have the right of reply when a magazine has published letters criticizing them.
the right to freedom of expression
Everyone has the right to freedom of expression.
right.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: used to show that you have understood or agree with what someone has just said
right.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: ‘You need to be there by ten o’clock.‘ ’Right.'
right.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: used to get someone’s attention before starting to say or do something
right.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: Right, open your books on page 16.
Right, I think we’re ready to go.
right.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: used to check if what you have said is correct
right.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: So we’re meeting in the pub, right?
right.translation[3].definitions[3].defi: used to check that the person you are speaking to is listening and understands what you are saying
right.translation[3].definitions[3].exam: So I handed him the camera, right, and asked him to take our photograph.
right.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: to put something back into the state or situation that it should be in
right.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: We must try to right the balance between taxation and government spending.
right.translation[4].definitions[1].defi: to put something, especially a boat, back into its correct upright position
right.translation[4].definitions[1].exam: I finally managed to right the canoe.
She righted herself and picked up her bag.
right.translation[5].definitions[0].defi: if you have the right to do something, you are morally, legally, or officially allowed to do it
right.translation[5].definitions[0].exam: Like other businesses, we have a right to set competitive prices.

New legislation is gradually taking away workers’ rights.
Your legal rights are the same when you buy mail order as when you buy from a shop.
right.translation[5].definitions[1].defi: rights offered to existing shareholders to buy more shares in a company, perhaps at a reduced price
right.translation[5].definitions[1].exam: The board approved a plan to raise $30 million through a stock rights offering.
right.translation[5].definitions[2].defi: if a person or company has the rights to something, they are legally allowed to use it to make money
right.translation[5].definitions[2].exam: They were granted the movie rights to her life story.
Warner will have all distribution rights in the U.S. and Canada.
